message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prions, which are associated with diseases such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and Variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, are notoriously difficult to inactivate and can survive sterilization using pressurized steam. Non-enveloped viruses, enveloped viruses, and yeasts are generally susceptible to sterilization using pressurized steam.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Steam sterilization at 121°C for 15 minutes is effective in killing non-enveloped and enveloped viruses, as well as yeasts. Prions, however, are highly resistant to most forms of sterilization and can survive the process. Therefore, reuse of instruments used in craniectomies can potentially cause transmission of prions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prions are the only option that can survive such a high temperature and pressure and can cause infection upon reuse of contaminated instruments. Non-enveloped viruses, enveloped viruses, and yeasts are all susceptible to destruction by pressurized steam.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prions are the only option that can withstand the high temperature and pressure of the sterilization process used for surgical equipment. Non-enveloped viruses, enveloped viruses, and yeasts are all susceptible to this process.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prions are the only option that can survive the sterilization process and cause transmission when instruments are reused. Non-enveloped viruses are easily destroyed by the sterilization process, and enveloped viruses and yeasts are also effectively eliminated by steam sterilization.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prions are the only option that can survive sterilization by pressurized steam and are a potential cause of transmission during reuse of sterilized instruments. Non-enveloped viruses and yeasts are generally susceptible to sterilization by pressurized steam, while enveloped viruses are inactivated by the process.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prions are the only option that can withstand and survive the sterilization process mentioned in the question. Non-enveloped and enveloped viruses can be destroyed by the process, and yeasts can be treated with lower temperatures and shorter duration of sterilization.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prions are able to survive steam sterilization at 121°C for 15 minutes and can lead to transmission if surgical equipment is not properly sterilized. Non-enveloped and enveloped viruses as well as yeasts are typically killed by this method of sterilization.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prions are the only pathogen among the options that are resistant to standard sterilization methods, such as pressurized steam at 121°C for 15 minutes. Non-enveloped viruses, enveloped viruses, and yeasts can be effectively sterilized using this method.

We refer to medical literature for help. Prions are the most resistant pathogen to sterilization methods and can survive even after being subjected to extreme conditions like pressurized steam at high temperatures. Non-enveloped viruses, enveloped viruses, and yeasts are not as resilient and can be effectively sterilized using conventional methods.
